Good question...that was a pretty vague article.  Does anyone know 
where the actual scientific publivacation is?  It sounded like 
a "shortcut" is a direct connection between two neurons that were 
previously only connected by a path.  There may be something to the 
idea of detecting common paths and temporarily replacing them with 
something simpler...though I don't really know if that's the main 
idea here.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> what are the 'short cuts' they are talking about?
> 
> chad
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> From: Mitchell Timin
> Sent: 5/20/2004 10:40:10 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [neat] If lemurs can do it ..............
> 
> 
> --- German Viscuso wrote:
> > For those peolple interested in short term memory
> > there's a recent article
> > here:
> > http://www.newscientist.com/news/news.jsp?
> 
> Yes, interesting. Possibly the original work to which
> they refer might have some applications for us. OTOH,
> whatever their topology was NEAT might be able to
> evolve it, without knowing what they did. I have no
> doubt that NEAT can evolve nets with short term
> memory. What is not clear is how much memory, i.e.
> given a reasonable amount of time for evolution, how
> much data can be stored and retrieved. It would also
> depend on the manner of retrieval.
> 
> =====
> Mitchell Timin
> http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
